title: God's Sovereignty in Creation
shortSummary: Job 39 highlights God's sovereign wisdom and power in the natural world by describing various animals and their behaviors that are beyond human control. This chapter emphasizes God's intimate knowledge and governance over creation, challenging Job to recognize human limitations and trust in divine providence.
timeline: Patriarchal Period, traditionally dated c. 2000-1800 BC

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The central figure of the book, a righteous man undergoing suffering, who is being questioned about his understanding of God's creation.

keyCharacters.name: The Wild Goat
keyCharacters.description: An example of God's creation used to illustrate natural processes beyond human control.

keyCharacters.name: The Unicorn
keyCharacters.description: A powerful, untamable animal symbolizing strength and independence, representing creatures God made beyond human mastery.

keyCharacters.name: The Ostrich
keyCharacters.description: A bird noted for its unusual behavior and lack of natural wisdom, demonstrating God's sovereign design even in apparent folly.

keyCharacters.name: The Horse
keyCharacters.description: A symbol of strength and warlike spirit, showing God's provision of power and courage for battle.

definitions.definition: In the KJV, likely refers to a strong wild ox or a now-extinct powerful animal, symbolizing untamable strength.
Female deer; used here to illustrate natural reproductive cycles.
A manger or feeding trough for animals, symbolizing domestication and service.
A container for holding arrows, representing warfare imagery in the description of the horse.
Seeks or searches for; used to describe the wild ass seeking food.

outline.heading: The Birth and Behavior of Wild Animals
outline.description: God questions Job about his knowledge of the reproductive cycles and independence of wild goats, hinds, and the wild ass, emphasizing that their lives are governed by divine design beyond human control.

outline.heading: The Untamable Strength of the Unicorn
outline.description: The unicorn is presented as a powerful creature that refuses to serve humans, illustrating the limits of human authority over God's creation.

outline.heading: The Ostrich’s Folly and God’s Wisdom
outline.description: The ostrich’s unusual nesting behavior and lack of natural wisdom highlight God's sovereign choice to withhold understanding from some creatures, contrasting human expectations.

outline.heading: The Horse’s Might and Courage in Battle
outline.description: The horse is depicted as a powerful and fearless warrior animal, demonstrating God’s provision of strength and courage for conflict.

outline.heading: The Hawk and Eagle’s Sovereign Flight
outline.description: The hawk and eagle obey God’s command in their flight and hunting, symbolizing divine control over even the most majestic creatures of the air.

application: Recognize and submit to God's sovereign control over all creation, trusting His wisdom beyond human understanding.
Embrace humility by acknowledging our limitations in knowledge and power compared to God's infinite wisdom.
Find encouragement in God's providential care, knowing He governs even the wildest parts of creation.
Cultivate faith that God equips His people with strength and courage for life's battles, just as He does for the horse.

keyVerses.text: Their young ones are in good liking, they grow up with corn; they go forth, and return not unto them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the independence God grants to His creatures, highlighting divine sovereignty over life cycles.

keyVerses.text: Will the unicorn be willing to serve thee, or abide by thy crib?
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the untamable nature of some creatures, symbolizing God's power beyond human control.

keyVerses.text: Hast thou given the horse strength? hast thou clothed his neck with thunder?
keyVerses.significance: This verse portrays God's gift of strength and majesty to the horse, a metaphor for divine empowerment.

keyVerses.text: Doth the hawk fly by thy wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south?
keyVerses.significance: It reminds us that even the instinctive flight of birds is under God's sovereign command, underscoring His comprehensive authority.
